description.text: For your egg.

This blaster was designed for Humans vs. Zombies.
With a small form-factor and magazine support, it is ideal for foam-flinging fun.
Supports 130 & 180 sized hobby motors.
Does not require, but works well with a 9/16" brass barrel.
The flywheels may work as is, but seeing as Styfe flywheels also fit, they have not been tested.
The holes to the battery tray fit XT60 connectors.
The biggest printing challenge is avoiding warping on the chassis print.
Please let me know of any suggestions for future designs, and I will endeavor to add them.
Additional information can be found in the README file.
Enjoy!

comments.author: Rccajack

comments.text: Thanks! I'll definitely be waiting for the V2, as I only have a 20x20cm plate. I noticed your flywheels aren't quite stock, what's that metal thing I see in them, and what is it for? I was wondering if you could also make a version without the canted flywheels (might be easy to add to the V2)? I'm also curious what printer you used to make yours, and what type of plastic you printed it in. Thanks for posting this, it's way cheaper than the other (almost) fully printed blasters I've found on here.
comments.author: MarkMarx1066

comments.text:
The only metal that can be seen in the flywheel area, should be the drive shafts of the motors.
The non-canted version will be make more sense in the Freigewehr-V2 due to its modularity. In fact, it should be quite easy to make a cage for whatever motor setup you want.
My printer is a first generation Rigidbot (10x10x10 inch build-space).
Typically I print in PLA, however ABS should work too (But be careful of lifting on the large print).
comments.author: Rccajack

comments.text: Is there a way that a the blaster could be printed on a small printer as my build space is only 120, by 120 by 120 mm or 12,12,12 cm or 5.3/4,5.3/4,5.3/4 inch. Is there a way to break these large peaces down to a manageable size for the little printers?
comments.author: Mickstar416

comments.text:
As of yet, I do not have a perfect solution.
My suggestion would be either to use one of the model-editors to chop (Front flywheel block from mid. Mid from back end. And then the mid and back into top and bottoms). Then, the pieces could be delicately assembled using a filament welding technique, or affixing everything to a custom brace (metal/wood).
I am currently working on a "more modular" design, but have not yet finished and tested it.
comments.author: Mickstar416

comments.text:
Quick update:
I have finished the designs for a modular blaster, fitting in a 12 x 12 x 12 cm buildspace.
First printing and assembly is happening in the next week, so hopefully I'll have share-able designs soon!

title: Power Supply cover for pixel lights

description.text:
This fits power supplies for Christmas light displays. Fits power supplies with a 113.5 x 50mm shell. It uses XT-60 connectors from RC cars for the power injection and power to the controller card. Each connector has an online fuse. The XT-60 connectors fit very tight and there is no need to glue them in place. They do take patience getting them in place so don't give up easy, they will fit. It is mainly for a cleaner look with less visible wires.

Rotate face down before slicing. Supports are built in for voltage display.

15A 125V Black Electrical Panel Mounted Screw Cap Fuse Holder
C14 Inlet Module Plug Fuse Switch Male Power Socket
XT60 Male Female Bullet Connectors Plugs For RC Lipo Battery
DC 3-30V Waterproof 3 Digits LED Digital Voltmeter

2/8/17
1A file gives a little more space for the voltage meter. It was too tight. Also lowered the screw mounts to the PS. Added a cover plate for the top. I have not printed it yet to test it out. Added US wiring diagram in photos.

2/9/17 Replaced cover plate for the top. The grill was too small and did not print well.

2/10/17 I built the EX60 connectors in one large block so it will be stronger. Also changed the size of the voltage screen area to make it easier to snap in. use the 1b stl.

author: dutchmogul

description.text: i made this for displaying my vintage Star Wars figures
Just added a bumper at the head area to absorb stronger hit.

Use this 4-port DB9 faceplate as a starting point for your own faceplate design for the Chameleon enclosure system found here: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9682 These can be laser cut, CNC routed, or 3D printed.

This model was produced by using a Creaform GoScan! 3D laser scanner to capture a sculpture of a female human head. This model is fairly minimal in terms of features, and makes a good calibration or demonstration print. In the spirit of the holiday, a scan of the head wearing a christmas hat was also taken.

Both models should be printed with support due to the overhangs on the chin and hat. I have had good results with 0.2 mm/layer, 2 perimeters all around, "fine" support density, and 20% infill using Kisslicer.

comments.text: Seems like this would be public domain. I have seen a few Styrofoam mannequin heads and glass vases that are using this exact same model, literally down to how the ear placement on one side is slightly indented. I think this is probably a scan of something like that. Cool head and a great starter mesh ready for modification. Thanks!

description.text:
This is a triple-axis tourbillon similar to those found in mechanical watches that are worth more than my life. The basic design mimics those of Thomas Prescher, who to the best of my knowledge, is the only purveyor of triaxial tourbillons that "fly" (ie. are cantilevered) about two axes.

See it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ARaZ5O9Wp8&feature=youtu.be
and here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iniAlhXM0p4&feature=youtu.be

A tourbillon supposedly improves accuracy through eliminating gravitational errors on the balance spring. It also increases both a watch's price and awesomeness on a sliding exponential scale based on the number of axes. This tourbillon utilizes a simple Swiss lever escapement vibrating at 14,400 bph. This is on the slow end by watch standards. The inner two axes run at 3 rpm while the outer ring turns at 1 rpm (provided one properly adjusts the balance with grub screws).

I tried to use the fewest and simplest parts in this design as well as the least amount of plastic. The largest part (the outer race) is 120mm x 136mm. It works quite nicely, but it could still use some improvements. Desired tweaks include the following:

  • Cutting properly sized 3mm shafts (I'm in the process of moving, so my Dremel is halfway across the ocean hence the extra long shaft and the nail).
  • Making a two-part outer race in order to eliminate the access hole in the giant bevel ring (you can see a few of the airsoft pellets making a bid for freedom).
  • Making it weight powered rather than hand powered.
  • Adding coin counterweights to balance the system.

Non printed parts:
4 x 6x2.5x3 RC Helicopter ball bearings
2mm shafts (various lengths)
3mm shaft (various lengths)
6mm airsoft pellets (about 60)

Here are links for the non-printed components I used. Anything comparable will do.
bearings: https://www.amazon.com/Sixteen-MR63-3x6x2mm-Precision-Bearings/dp/B01M0VV96I/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1483062996&sr=8-2&keywords=3mm+id+ball+bearing
3mm rods: https://www.amazon.com/10Pcs-Stainless-Steel-Cylinder-Linear/dp/B00JR56KI0/ref=sr_1_1?rps=1&ie=UTF8&qid=1483063060&sr=8-1&keywords=3mm+shaft&refinements=p_85%3A2470955011
2mm rods: https://www.amazon.com/20Pcs-Stainless-Steel-Round-150mmx2mm/dp/B00KHUR5AQ/ref=sr_1_1?rps=1&ie=UTF8&qid=1483063100&sr=8-1&keywords=2mm+shaft&refinements=p_85%3A2470955011
airsoft pellets: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002GNYDCA/ref=od_aui_detailpages00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Printer:

Reach 3d

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Printed at 195/60. The balance wheel is at 100% while all else is at 30%. Only framea, the outer race, and the 10t bevel require supports.

The 10t bevel, and the outer race are designed to firmly grip their 3mm shaft. All others should spin freely.

title: 20mm test cube with zero tolerance round plug

description.text:
20mm test cube to check dimensions.

Includes a 10mm round hole and a 10mm round peg. Ideally the peg should be able to fit in the hole!

I found with Simplify3D set with horizontal size compensation of -0.05mm the plug can be forced in to the hole just about, and external dimensions spot on 19.99 or 20.03. Height was very close at 20.20. This was using colorfab PLA/PHA at 200C on a Lulzbot TAZ6.

I have also added a second version with 10mm boxes on each axis to test internal dimensions.

description.text: Because these printers (Dremel3D20) are heavy 7-8Kg with servo's playing discordant noise through feet, table floor and sometimes quiet regions of the house, I needed a damper/isolator. I tried http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:615325 but of course these were too weak to cope with the mass. I saw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213696 which gave me more ideas. This is split in two parts, feet inserts and damper rings.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Printed on Standard settings on Dremel 3D20 IdeaBuilder via Autodesk PrintStudio. You may also want to add self-adhesive rubber pads to add further damping and reduce creep.

Assembly

First Part is a replacement for the standard black rubber foot in each corner of the printer. Its a curved section around 4-5cm in size. Remove them and replace with my angled foot which had two locating slots. These fit into the damper rings.
Take the damper rings and I added a small rubber self-adhesive pad to stop any creep of the printer on my desk - just in case. Fit two damper rings to each corner (needed for weight) and can only fit one way and your done. Blue dremel filament matches the blue lid :)

Parts were designed to print the box vertically without supports which meant the brackets were different. The top bracket fits on the inside lip of the box where the recessed section is in the wall of the box. This secures the top to the cupboard. The bottom bracket is a simple L shaped platform to bear the weight. A gusset would add strength, but the whole mass is quite light so decided not to add one.

This is an adapter that tips the palm pre touchstone up so that it is easier to see on a dashboard, high shelf etc. I made it for my car where it works really really well as a mount when combined with the touchstone.
It is easy to adjust the angle of the mount in a CAD program. It would look good in black ABS. I made it on our Z Corp machines at www.lgm3d.com and painted it black.

Print this.
Stick the Touchstone on one side and stick the other to your dashboard or shelf.
If your dash is curved, you can put a piece of sandpaper on the dash, (smooth side to the dash) and use it to sand the base to fit.
I used VHB tape to stick it down to the dash. The Touchstone does not need additional tape to stick it to this adapter.

title: Safe and secure Raspberry Pi Case

description.text:
This case is a remix of many cases all at once. I've picked the best ideas I found around and merged them into one single case. This case has thicker walls and as such, it does not flex like most of the cases you can find on thingiverse. I've made many fine adjustments, and added the use of screws to secure the case against tampering. There is also a door mat for the SD card that protects it from accidental pull or bend. The Raspberry Pi inside the case is a B model with 2011,12 markings next to the Pi logo. You can find the other Safe and Secure cases here: Case for the Raspberry Pi A+:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566506 Case for the Raspberry Pi B+:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:423216 Raspberry Pi 3 & 2 B:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427797 Enjoy.

I have printed this at .25mm layer height with a .35 nozzle using 2 perimeters and 80% infill. No support.  
Fasten with 4x 20mm M3 socket screws & nuts.

comments.text: Perhaps it just my lack of experience, but I'm struggling with this print.  Even with a 6mm wide brim on a fresh piece of BuildTak, I'm getting curling/lifting with various PLA at 208C, .25mm layers, and many (.5, .8, 1.0) infill densities.  Any words of wisdom you'd like to share?  I've also flattened my aluminum bed considerably and have a Printrbot Simple/Metal with auto-bed leveling.  Thanks!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text:
To be frank with you, I have never used brim on any of my prints. When I first tried PLA, I had the hardest time with it, until I discovered 2 things: A, the darker the filament, the more pigment it has, and the harder to print it is (at least for me), B, the distance from the bed to the nozzle is absolutely critical.
Many say use a piece of paper when you zero in your Z. I call bull on that, simply because, no one dare to mention the type of paper and its weight (quality goes with weight, as a 500 sheet packet of different qualities will weight differently, and each piece of paper will have a different thickness).
You must invest in a long feel gauge kit, got mine for 8.99 on the bay, and I do not regret it a bit. I use the .25 feel gauge, and zero in my bed. With the feel gauge, I was able to make prints from 0.05 and higher. But I don't print huge parts with this kind of layer height as it just takes forever.
Lastly, once you are absolutely sure you nozzle is .25 from your bed, then you need to look at your slicer settings. First, you never want to have the fan on for the first layer, and if you print 3 solid layers at the bottom, then no fan for the first 3 layers.
Then you need to adjust the width of your extrusion. I mean by that, that I set an extrusion width of 125% of my nozzle width for the first layer (in slicer, the setting is called First Layer Height under the Print Settings/Layers and Perimeters tab. This will squish the extrusion together, making it denser, and will obviously make the first layer a little bit wider that it is in your gcode, but it is easy to remove with an x-acto.
My current slicer settings are as follows for a .35 nozzle.

The reason for making this, was because no suitable holder was available anywhere in stores, neither online nor brick and mortar store. All standard holders have axle parallelly with wall and distance between axle and wall is not enough for bigger rolls. Because I have availability to purchase jumbo rolls, I need to make my own holder. Obviously, standard arrangements (axis parallelly woth wall) is not suitable for such size of roll, therefore it have to be upright to the wall.
I used anchor screws for plaster walls (Easyfix Hollow Wall Anchors), as you can see on picture from packing and when mounted in the wall.

This solution is easy for anytime remove holder (and eventually move to different place).
In case of plaster wall it have one slight disadvantage: rolling on this holder create vibrations, which are transfered from holder to the wall and somehow amplified with plaster board. Can cause discomfort for for some...
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g2iaZk6Woad

title: Ultimate Laptopstand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my "One Plug everything Works" solution

I wanted a Laptop Stand with intigrated USB Typ C Hub (with HDMI Out, DC In, SD Card Reader and 3 USB Tyb B Slots) So I bought that:

https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B019RAYMSE/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

HDMI Cable:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B01C8TN0N4/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I also wanted to have an External HDD in my stand:

https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00CRZ2G7Q/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

And i made an extra Space for my:

Solemate Speaker under the stand
And an SD Card Hoder
and some Space for my Intenso USB Stick:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00FJ9JODG/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I put all these Things togeter into my Laptopstand.

Goal for me was to just plug one Cable in to my Laptop and get a full Workingspace with an Second Screen, Mouse and USB Hub everything without to Plug extra DC cable (it is Integrated in the Hoo Too Hub)and no Cables in the front.For me this is the Perfect solution.

I made two parts because of the print sice of my Ultimaker Original. So I had to stick it together with glue

Maybe you can also need it

Hi everyone! I let you here a design I have made for a flexible purse. I printed it on filaflex so first I want to say sorry for the photos cause you know that this kind of materials get dirty really easily.

As you all know, filaflex settings are a bit different than for PLA or ABS. Print it with a low speed (20/40ms) and 0.2 high layer. Be sure to print the file with a 100% or high percent infill so the walls of the purse work propertly when you press it to open.

It can be used with money but you can also use it for carrying every small object you want. Dont be shy to comment or suggest any improvements.

If you liked the design or it was usefull please hit the like button so more people can discover this too!

comments.text: Hi! The inside of the print is a messy cause of the support material. The yellow one was a complete desaster at first and I had to make a huge cleaning. I printed it in with Anet A8 with retraction disabled and 100% infill. I also used Filaflex from BQ. Maybe the problem comes with your support settings. Make it sure to have solid support structure so the the overhanglayer gets printed as it should. I hope this helps! :)

This thing was inspired by "Desktop Christmas Tree Star Topper" uploaded by marvec6. I took that stl, and revised it so it could be printed in two halves and glued together to make a whole. Note this is a small tree topper. 118mm wide.

I used 1 shell and 15% infill, no supports are required. You will probably have to sand the two mating surfaces prior to gluing (due to slight warpage at the extremes), or perhaps glue and then use filler such as spackle or silicone prior to painting.  
I've added .sat, .stp and .igs files which are 3d solids files (three different file formats) for those who wish to experiment.

description.text:
This is the logo for the Canadian Digital Service. The top section, the crown, is to be painted or rendered in gold or a golden colour, while the bottom section of the leaf may be rendered in Canadian Red, or silver, or black, or white, or maybe whatever is the last colour of filament you have around. The top part must be gold!

The SVG of the Canadian Maple Leaf used to make this design is included as well, for future reference.

This is to be worn the same way a Starfleet communicator badge is worn. ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communicator_(Star_Trek) ) As part of the uniform of the Canadian Digital Service.

The Canadian Digital Service shares its soul with the best in Starfleet, and the best in Canada: Our respect for human rights, liberties and freedoms, for advancement in medicine, science, technology, culture. Wearing this indicates that the wearer declares openly their respect for the individual, and their optimism that it is possible to make a better future.

A fastener must be contrived, probably something like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1256263

Update after first print: shrinking to a vertical (top point to bottom stem) length of 6cm gives a better size, and gold paint on the crown looks pretty good! I taped a safety pin to the back for this first prototype, but it's promising!
The stem might benefit from some thickening, but we'll see.
JOIN THE CANADIAN DIGITAL SERVICE TODAY! SERVE YOUR FELLOW HUMANS! MAKE A BRIGHTER FUTURE!

Next up, adding a recessed pin spot to the back, and creating a nametag generator (favourite font right now: 'press start') probably in openSCAD.

description.text:
Shane @ Fugatech 3D Printing reviewed this spool as part of his January Maker Box video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eBWand6m6G4

To address his concerns... because the size (diameter) of the wind on the Maker Box samples varies so much in my experience, I had to decide whether to make this on the smaller or larger end of the size range I measured among my samples. Because I wanted this to keep the filament neat & tidy on the spool, I opted to design it on the larger side of that diameter range. When I am using a sample that is smaller than the spool, I just lay the sample onto the hub, put my fingers into the inside diameter of the filament, & wiggle to expand it onto the hub. Easy peasy.

***At least 1 person said that they resized this to ~87% in their slicer & the result required no fiddling to get their MakerBox samples to fit.

This is my 2nd remix of the same original spool by Tamel55. The first time, I simply remixed his Small Spool to thicken the inner walls behind the threads for easier printing & added strength. This time, I just re-used his threaded center section to create a spool designed specifically for use with Maker Box filament samples. These tend to be about 40-50g each, and I measured a typical diameter of about 140mm on the loose filament- I think it generally uncoils to about the width of the baggie it's shipped in.

The innermost opening, where the spool is meant to go over the holder on your machine, is between 41-42mm. This was enough to fit the OEM holder on my Wanhao/Maker Select i3. The outer rim where the filament resides is 140mm. I can easily lay a Maker Box sample on one half of the spool, then lay the other half on top & screw it into place.

There are 50-degree angled anchor holes in the outer rim if you want to anchor your sample to the spool, as well as 50-degree angled anchor holes along the outermost edge to let you secure the business end of your filament sample so it doesn't go all squirrely on you.

***The anchor holes on each half of the spool are angled in opposite directions so you don't have to worry about which direction the filament goes onto the spool- you just use which ever holes line up properly.

***Due to a user requests, there are now 3 versions of this spool holder in the .stl files. One is printable on 200mm print beds, the others are broken into halves or quarters for smaller print beds (minimum 100x100), and would need to be glued together. I have not attempted to print & assemble these, but I imagine a good 2 part epoxy would be the best adhesive. And be sure to match the THREADS on the pieces before gluing together.

***PLEASE NOTE: This spool is meant to HOLD the Maker Box samples. One of those samples would never be enough to make one. Just to be perfectly clear.

comments.text: I'm not sure what to tell you, except that if the filament sample is too small in diameter, you need to get your fingers inside it & wiggle them to expand the sample. comments.text: Good morning... just finished cutting the objects into 4 pieces each.  The pieces are 90x90mm, so easily printable on a 150mm bed, even a 100mm bed.  Have not tried printing & assembling them.  I would imagine a 2 part epoxy would work best for durability, especially since tightening the threads will stress those glue joints.  ALSO, before gluing, be sure to align those threads to each other to make sure you're not gluing with pieces in the wrong spots.  If I was better at CAD, I would have tried to make the joints different so they wouldn't match if they were in the wrong spots, but I'm not.  lol  So be careful.  Hate to see you print for hours & then ruin it by forgetting to check the threads before gluing.  :-)  (That sounds like something I would do)
comments.author: nscxp2005

comments.author: Fuganater

comments.text: I've found that the MakerBox samples are somewhat inconsistent in their coil diameter.  I mean, they're only packaged in Ziploc bags, after all.  I measured the coil size of 6 different samples from different months & found them between 120-145mm.  (So about an inch variance, as you note)  I opted to make the spool diameter 140mm so that the spools with the loosest wind would fit fairly well.  The more tightly wound samples, I just put my fingers into the coil & gently "pry" them open enough to fit on the spool by wiggling my fingers.

description.text:
The final product of many inspirations and iterations. I Present to you the low profile zmr 250 mod. This frame set comes complete with 15 degree motor tilts, a mobius camera mount and of course, the frame and skid plates.

comments.author: WarHawk8080

comments.text: I wonder what is the purpose of using the halbach array in this configuration?  Would it be more efficient than just a round magnet with a series of cylindrical coils? Using a sleeve around the magnets, you will be fighting resistance of the physical casing.  With a tubular design, the pressure points will be more dispersed and would be a smooth nickel neo against filament, instead of filament against filament.  I would use magnets on each end to aid the back and forth motion, storing the return energy.  To charge even a single 18650 in a reasonable amount of time, you will need a really efficient generator design.
comments.author: WarHawk8080

comments.text:
Do not make an inductor like AMPY
http://drop-kicker.com/2016/01/ampy-move-teardown-and-review/
http://drop-kicker.com/2014/11/ampy-and-juse/
If you still want to use a round magnets make it better in the inductor "Magic Candle"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2001101
See how the current in the coil is formed with a round magnet
https://www.khanacademy.org/science/physics/magnetic-forces-and-magnetic-fields/magnetic-flux-faradays-law/a/what-is-faradays-law
https://www.comsol.com/blogs/computing-voltages-produced-electromagnetic-induction/
comments.author: JcDenton

comments.text: Only thing I can think of is that it increases the overall magnetism and flux on the outside of the array, moreso than even a round magnet could manage.  I still think it would take hours of "shaking" it to get any kind of charge...and the problem of being charge pulse spikes rather than a smooth charge could cause issues with the Li Ion batteries
comments.author: JcDenton

author: AdriL

title: Screw/ Worm drive filament extruder Bowden

description.text:
A 3D printer filament driver for a bowden setup utilizing a wood screw and geared stepper motor. This drive unit is capable of provding significantly higher forces than a traditional filament extruder because of the increased number of engaged teeth and the mechanical advantage of the worm gear/ wood screw. The wood screw is designed to be easily replaceable by unscrewing the tensioner bolt and poping out the screw, then putting the spring on the new screw, compressing the spring and inserting into the slot. The spring pressure on the screw holds the driver securely into the screws head to prevent slop.
The filament enters the top of the assembly through a filleted hole, passes in-between the spring loaded hinge and a wood screw, forcing the filament to travel the length of the wood screw and out the push to connect fitting. The wood screw is held in position by a compression spring and is supported by two 1/8'' rods. note some images are slightly outdated. This is an experimental filament driver based on Werner Berry's concept described here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWKe1mUl8bw&noredirect=1 Bill of Materials:
1x 5'' long, 1/8'' diameter steel or stainless steel rod for hinge
2x 1.12'' long 1/8'' diameter steel or stainless steel rod for screw support
1x compression spring. McMaser 1986K930 for hinge pressure
1x Compression spring McMaster 1986K710 for securing screw
1x 2in wood screw (sharper threads the better).
1x Matching 1/4'' hex driver for chosen wood screw
shaft coupler for motor to hex screw driver
1x McMaster 91251A875 Tensioner Bolt for hinge
1x washer for tensioner bolt and spring
2x thin profile nylock 1/4-20 nuts for lever arm and tensioner bolt McMaster 90101A007
1x push to connect tube adapter (filament exit) McMaster 5779K117
1x shoulder screw for lever axle. McMaster 91273A301
4x. your choice thread tapered head mounting screws for assembly
4x M3 stepper motor tapered thread screws.
1x geared stepper motor. I chose the Kysan 1040212 Geared Stepper Motor. 26.4Kg-cm. NEma 17. for $45 at http://www.kysanelectronics.com/Products/Detail.php?recordID=5180 Warning: Due to the relatively small bend radius the filament needs to follow, there is a chance of PLA filament breaking. If this happens, please let me know and I'll increase the bend radius in a bug fix. Bug Fixes:
180 degree filament curve added to help prevent filament twist.

comments.text: I had the same epiphany driving home from work today and quickly googled it when I got home, and here we are :)
comments.author: Prot0typ1cal

comments.text: not so new idea  its is used on the old Rapman extruder
comments.author: vvdd

comments.text: Okay... What about some kind of razor blade? It could be used to prevent filament rotating, I think
comments.author: Renha

comments.text: Good idea. It might help a bit. My primary concern would be with the shear strength of the plastic not being able to take the force from the razor blade, resulting in shavings piling up in the drive system. But if the razor blade was distributed over a sufficiently long piece of plastic, it shouldn't be a problem!
comments.author: Renha

comments.text: what about using 2 screws - one left and one right, to prevent filament rotation?
comments.author: Renha

comments.text: Hi Renha, I did consider using 2  counter-rotating screws to prevent twisting, but with the configuration this device is in, I would be worried about any gear backlash associated with coupling the two screws. Any amount of backlash would likely result in the destruction of the screws or the gears as well as contribute to extruder inaccuracies. If two screws were to be used, I would further develop the counter-rotating screw adaptation under remixes. I thought that was very clever. However, the backlash issue needs to be addressed some more.
comments.author: Renha

comments.text: Socket head wood screw with flats grinding to the shaft of the motor?
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: The wood screw is coupled to the motor via a short driver bit found at hardware stores. There is also a shaft coupler which joins the bit to the motor shaft.
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text:
Interesting note, this has also been done by Stratasys, and I imagine others. See this patent:https://www.google.com/patents/US20100283172?dq=inassignee:%22Stratasys,+Inc.%22+consumable+assembly&ei=yqetU7mNGcrfoASHwoDAAg&cl=enhttps://www.google.com/patents...
Figures 11 and 12 show a similar assembly built into a quick swap extruder head.
comments.author: pyrophreek

comments.text: You're right! Big similarity. I know the concept has been around for years but didn't get much attention due to twisting problems. My design is special with the twist in the filament path. I'm curious how stratasys addressed it.
comments.author: pyrophreek

comments.text:
Not sure, but I imagine a screw mounted at an angle equal to the pitch of the threads, which presses into the filament above the worm drive would work to prevent rotation.
On another note, I have been looking into designs for multi extruder assemblies and I saw this design: http://www.lateral-i.com/a-multiple-extruder-on-a-rotating-turret-ide-for-fff-fdm-3d-printers/http://www.lateral-i.com/a-mul...
I like the idea of a rotating turrent because the motion could also be used to pull the nozzles up out of the way by using a track which pulls each nozzle up as it rotates out of the home position. A wiping assembly as shown in this design could also be included to prevent any drooling, although it could consist simply of small pieces of metal at each of the park positions rather than a long track as shown in the linked design.
What I was thinking was that you could use a worm drive such as your design, with a spur gear on the end of each drive rod. These would then index, along with the nozzle, to a worm gear on the drive motor. The double reduction from the worm drives would drastically reduce the torque required to move the filament (although high speed extrusion might be a problem especially with stepper motors). For the indexing system, a geneva gear system could also be used to reduce the precision needed for the indexing motor (a simple DC geared motor could be used, with a tiny sensor to detect when one rotation has occured).
I do not have the time or the capabilities to properly develop this idea, so I am suggesting it to you in the hopes that maybe it interests you and you can have some fun designing and implementing it.
comments.author: GadgetGuru314

comments.text:
Interesting concept and I see where you're going with this. I can see how being able to change nozzles (or colors) on the fly would be useful in a print that requires varying accuracy at different locations (ie the fill versus the perimeter). Compounded by the use of only 2 motors, it would be light weight and would operate at higher speeds.
I do have some reservations with the design though. I'm concerned the mechanical complexity is too high to be practical. I wouldn't recommend rotating the entire hot end assembly because maintaining its position in space relative to the print within a few thousandths of an inch is paramount. I also foresee repeatability being an issue with the nozzles lifting out of the way each time, it will be difficult to get their height exactly* right each time it is lowered again. A piece of dirt or crud could really mess the system up. I like your idea of using a worm gear, but it's been expressed to me that using worm gears alone for an extruder isn't optimal because its difficult to retract fast enough to prevent drooling. The geneva mechanism for indexing the nozzles is also clever.
When you first described the concept, it reminded me of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16429http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
I like your idea, -it has several clever elements to the design. But, I think the design above would be more reliable than a turret design. Keep those creative juices flowing!
comments.author: pyrophreek

comments.text:
I agree that the rotating turret design would require very high precision to ensure that as the each nozzle came into position it fell into precisely the same position each time. I wonder if a guide could be built into the design such that as the geneva gear rotated to the lock position, it pushed the hot end down into a holder which would ensure precise positioning. Unfortunately I don't think this design would work well with 3D printed parts, and would require high precision machined parts to work best, then again if you relied on a spring loaded mechanism to hold the nozzle into the guide, you might be able to have some slop in the system, but still maintain good precision. The hotend and worm drive would have to be as small as possible, as the entire assembly would have to be spring loaded, similar to the patent I linked earlier.
The major use I see for a system like this is for multi material and color parts as the ability to lift the parked nozzles would help prevent damage to the parts and drooling. Also it would be relatively simple to build in a sort of capping mechanism for the parked nozzles to prevent any drooling as well. This would circumvent the need for nozzle priming and wiping towers and ooze shields. Another advantage is that as you add more nozzles to a system, all of the offsets either reduce the printable area of your printer, or require a larger positioning system for the same size build plate, while with this design the active nozzle is always in the same position, and as long as the assembly fits on your system, you will still have the full build area. One final caveat, you would have to ensure that the turret never rotated more than one rotation though or you would a problem with the multiple filaments tangling, but this could be handled relatively easily in software.
comments.author: GadgetGuru314

comments.text: Hi, Im borowing this idea to make a Delta printer at my university, what I would like to know is: why you made two 3mm channels on top of the 1.75mm channel for the filament? Also, do you believe there would be any problems modifying this to fit 3mm filament?
comments.author: xaliax

comments.text: Hi Xaliax, the two 3mm channels on top of the filament are to reduce friction between the hinge piece and the filament so the moving back and forth doesn't build up heat and fuse the filament and hinge piece together. I see no reason the design can't be modified to handle 3mm filament. However, just a word of advice- 3mm filament is becoming outdated, 1.75mm filament is becoming dominant because of its ability to extrude smaller volumes per linear increment (due to cross sectional volume). As a result, it's becoming increasingly difficult to find new or replacement parts for 3mm filament. If you still want to use 3mm filament, let me know and I'll post another version for 3mm filament. i don't think the filament channel in the hinge will comfortably fit 3mm filament.
comments.author: xaliax

comments.text: Just a heads up, this was done a long time ago in the RepRap community, like...2008. You should check out this history of reprap: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/22464622/A%20History%20of%20RepRap%20Development.pdfhttp://dl.dropbox.com/u/224646... -- it causes twisting in the filament, and generally gave people a bunch of problems.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: What do you think of the bug fix?

sorry for sticking my nose where it does not belong, but I like the design, the only thing that i'm not sure is, where would you put that drive extruder on the printer, because the filament input angle is the same as the output. maybe the filament roll should be in an upper position? for example lake this image.
comments.author: GadgetGuru314

comments.text:
Na, I like noses- as long as they're not too pointy.
Your point is valid. The photobucket image you linked is similar to what I had in mind. This extruder was designed for a delta printer with both the filament and filament extruder on the top of the 3D printer. The Filament was intended to be mounted roughly in front or above the extruder. As your drawing indicates, the tube is intended to leave the extruder and go up and then back down to the extruder head. Obviously not all 3d printers have the same architecture so I guess we'll just have to make it work with other printers. If it becomes a big problem, i'll make a bug fix.
comments.author: JAP

comments.text: Thank you for the heads up. That's a very valid concern and I can see how it would be problematic. I'll update the design with a bug fix shortly.
Any other suggested improvements?
comments.author: GadgetGuru314

comments.text:
While this design isn't optimal or minimal in a few areas, its designed to be built with no minimal machined parts (short of 3-d printed parts). The shaft coupler between the hex driver and stepper shaft could even be replaced by a Jiffy Weld bond. My only concern there is if the shafts aren't perfectly in line the bond might break from sheer stress.
Thank you all for your suggestions. I'll post a revised version within the next few days
comments.author: GadgetGuru314

comments.text: along with what JAP said, i think that you may want to put a larger angle on the filament as it comes in, as it is it makes a pretty large bend that will jam a lot. looks fantastic and will definitely be making one once there is another one out there!
comments.author: Tom_Maragos

comments.text: Thank you for your feeback Tom. Increasing the bend radius will reduce stress on the filament (although with this configuration I doubt jaming is possible. I'd imagine the filament would break before the drive slips) My concern is the entrance angle. If the entrance angle is too severe, there will be stress there as well. This all depends on where the spool is located relative to the drive unit.
comments.author: Tom_Maragos

comments.text:
Bits From Bytes (BFB) printers has used worm drive extruders for years. http://www.bitsfrombytes.com/sites/bitsfrombytes.com/files/downloads/V2.0.0AndV2.0.1/ExtruderAssembly.pdfhttp://www.bitsfrombytes.com/s...
Further, the RepRap folks did it even before them http://reprap.org/wiki/ThermoplastExtruderhttp://reprap.org/wiki/Thermop...
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: While i'm aware this is not a new concept, using a replacable wood screw is a unique solution. This design also has fewer components than the bitsfrombytes design and this one is meant for a Bowden Setup
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Wow amazing concept, I think, probably, this model would be more stable and precise, but not sure about the part of the lid, as the movement of the filament would make the canal filament deeper even if it fits with the adjustment screw as the first extruder, maybe if the lid has 2 or 3 lined bearings for wear would be less.
comments.author: JAP

comments.text: Thanks for the Feeback JAP. you're right, it wouldn't be a bad idea to reduce friction between the filament and the hinge. I'll add two more steel rods for it to ride against in the next revision.
comments.author: JAP

comments.text: Hello again, i was checking, and thanks for taking my suggestion, but i have a doubt, my mechanical is not good, I hope it could be understandable, let's say that the extruder is aligned on the X axis, the filament is outing on this axis, but if i'm correct the rods wouldn't rotate because they are aligned too on the X axis, maybe if you use pellets or bearings aligned, the filament would have less friction
comments.author: GadgetGuru314

comments.text: I don't think the rods will rotate when the screw is turning because the joint is so snug on the bottom and the filament won't be rotating so the rods aren't even in contact on the top.

I reworked the Design and used the Spreadsheet-Workbench in FreeCAD the first time. Now you can adjust the Conduit Diameters to your needs and also Tweak the Tolerances for your 3d Printer.

Recently i often used plastic conduit, because it was lying around at work a lot, so the Idea of a foldable Guitar Stand came to my mind.

I used 16mm plastic Conduit for the Feet and 20mm plastic conduit for the main boom. All is glued together with hot glue. I cutted the rear Foot opposite to the Guitar holder until the Tripod leaned back the right angle.

The weight of a guitar is bending the boom and the feet a little bit, but it looks stable so far. In fact the bending feet work like springs. if you bump into the tripod it gives way and swings back to position.

I use plastic conduit like these:
16mm: EAN Code 4013960179767
20mm: EAN Code 4013960179774

title: Nixie Tube Clock IN-12B (Bezel & High voltage guard)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a Nixie Tube clock, as the electronics require circa 170 Volts, there is a danger of getting a shock, so what you see here are protective covers that provide a shroud insulating the many live terminals.
The bezel also provides a great base whilst soldering the back wires onto the Nixietube sockets, also giving a good base and separation of the tube pairs.
It is of a pretty generic design with lots of mounting holes, so should fit into any box.
The Nixie tubes came from the Ukraine, they are classed as NOS (New Old Stock), circa 30 years old, still wrapped in original waxed paper.
The bases were also of this age period (bakelite) , as you can they oxidized a tad so needed burnishing with a dremel polisher.
The IN-12B types have the extra decimal point, IN-12A do not.
The IN-12B Nixie tubes need circa 170 Volts to strike the pleasing glowing arc, this is achieved with a power FET switching an inductor on/off very quickly ---basic inverter--- using an Atmega Chip.
At this stage of the project there are lots of 170 Volts things to be touched.
The INS-1 separator colons are neat too... an upgrade from your normal "mains plug" type.
To prolong the Nixie tubes life, the dimmer you use them the longer the life.......
A dud 10mm LED was sawn off and hollowed out with a dremel to contain the LDR which was glued into place with epoxy glue (scratches magically disappear as the LED material is also epoxy). The LDR effectively alters the PWM signal to the 170 Volt inverter circuit and allows the display to be dimmed by duty cycle.
To contain the 170 Volts a 3D back/front shroud was made, this also allowed a good spacing for the tubes and allowed the colon indicators to slot neatly between the tube pairs.
They were designed to give each Nixie a kinda sun shade, which gives added clarity.
As you can see below the mass of wiring shoehorns neatly into the protective shroud.
The box is out of wood and bashed together to create the vintage look, it was a pig of a job to cut the front bezel.
It uses a small RTC module to keep the clock in sync.

description.text: Made this beer barrel opener tool for my old man as his arthritis makes it difficult to open the barrel unassisted. There are two version, one has a smoother handle as the stepped version can be a little harsh to grip. If i had a bigger build plate then i would extend and widen the handles. It was based on KingKeg barrel lids, it fits both barrels we have.

No

No

.30

75

Notes:

I wanted this part to be as strong as possible, this is why the resolution and infill is so high. I also printed with a 3 shell thickness.

I traced the lid of a king keg barrel and used a caliper to get the various dimensions of the fins and outer diameter of the lid. Then mocked up the shape in 3DS Max using the "measure and select" extension (http://www.scriptspot.com/3ds-max/scripts/miauu-measure-and-select).

I wanted the part to be printed in one piece as i felt it wouldn't be strong enough if i had to assemble it. This part utilizes the whole build plate of my flash-forge creator. I tried rotating the tool so the handles would extend to corner but then the slimmed section would be directly attached the handle which could weaken the tool.

The handles could be extended if you have a bigger print area.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed it topside down to get best stiffness. The model was adjusted to print without supports.

description.text:
This is a mount for the Geeetech 3D-Touch / BLTouch Sensor for Anet A8 printers.

This design is meant for people which do not use an extruder cooling fan and heatsink.

(Both are not really needed as shown by multiple experiments of different users. Please no discussions about that ;-)

I included the Fusion 360 file which makes it easy to modify if needed.

The mount fits right onto the side of the extruder using the original (shorter) screws. It has little holes for the nuts of the sensor screws to make assembling easy. After assembling the sensor is very stiff connected to the j-frame. It will hardly move or bend on usage. I printed the mount with BDP (GreenTec) filament but I think normal PLA will do. The sensor distance should fit for the standard A8 extruder out of the box.

I also included some information on how to connect the sensor to the Anet motherboard.

The first two images show the sensor mounted to the extruder. The second two images are showing the "draft" wiring and the last three images show my final wiring.

It uses the "LED pin" which is an unused pin on the A8 (using the stock 5 button 2004 LCD). That is the third wire counted from below (where the red marker is on the cable). I simply spliced the cable and cut that wire. This will be the servo signal (yellow).

On the A6, you can use wire no. 7 and FW pin 29. I could verify that with the A6 display I have available.

The +5V (red) and GND (brown/black) are available at the z-end-stop connector as is the signal itself (white).

You can simply connect the black and brown wire of the sensor to the GND from the z-end-stop socket. This leaves you with 4 instead of 5 wires from the sensor to the board. On the first of the second two images you can see how I used some patch cables and a wire clamp to draft the connection at the board. In the second of the two images you can see the wiring at the sensor.

After everything worked well I have chosen an old usb mouse cable. Those have exactly 4 wires. I used green for the sensor, red for +5v, black for GND and yellow for the servo signal (originating from the LCD cable). I crimped a fitting connector for the z-end-stop socket and a single connector for the connection to the spliced LCD cable. I also soldered the other end of those 4 wires directly to the PCB inside of the sensor. Soldering is not needed and can be a pain. Beware not to destroy your sensor if you do it. You can see the result in the last three images.

Setting up SkyNet3D / Marlin (the firmware) is pretty straightforward. Besides the entries for the auto bed levelling you need to make the following entries:

#define BLTOUCH
#define SERVO0_PIN 27

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -20
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -15
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

#define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP_INVERTING false

I also used:

#define Z_CLEARANCE_DEPLOY_PROBE   5
#define Z_CLEARANCE_BETWEEN_PROBES  5

#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200

After mounting and uploading the new firmware you can test you sensor:

M280 P0 S10 ; pushes pin down
M280 P0 S90 ; drags pin up
M280 P0 S120 ; does selftest (pin up/down continuously)

M280 P0 S160 ; reset alarm

M280 P0 S60 ; switch triggering test mode
; move pin at the sensor up or down manually
M119  ; reports state of the endstop
; pin up (LED on) z_min should read TRIGGERED
; pin down (LED off) z_min should read open

If your sensor does not selftest but blinks directly or after some few alternating motions you need to adjust the screw in the top of the sensor. One of the allen wrenches which are part of the printer does fit right in. Lose the screw until the light went off, then fasten the screw until it is lit again. I needed some time to find the sweet sport. Using selftest and reset alarm until it worked well.

Finally you can try a G28 command. If everything is OK it will probe twice in the middle of the bed. The tip will go down and up again as soon it touches the surface of the bed. If not you need to check cables and settings.

To adjust the z offset I use the following easy and pretty failsaife procedure:

; preheat for working temperatures
(M502 ; optionally reset to firmware settings)
M851 Z0 ; reset any z-offset
G28 ; home all
G1 X110 Y110 ; move nozzle in center
M211 S0 ; disable software endstop
; now move your nozzle manually onto the bed such that it (strongly) grips paper.
G92 Z0 ; tell the printer that this is Z = 0
G30 X110 Y110 ; move the sensor over the center and let it trigger
; note what z position G30 reports, that, negated, is your z offset
M851 Z-1.23 ; register that z offset (here 1.23 as example)
M500 ; store those values into the EEPROM

You may want to do some G30 X110 Y110 commands to validate how well your sensor works. It should report the same values +/- 0.0x.

You can also enable Z_MIN_PROBE_REPEATABILITY_TEST in the firmware and use M48 L10 P8 V4 to let it test repeatability at the same point with a lot of fake movement in between probes.

There are occasions where the sensor after power on gives an error with the G28 command for no obvious reason. I found that the sequence:

M280 P0 S160 ; Reset 3D-Touch
G4 P500
M280 P0 S10 ; Pin out
G4 P500
M280 P0 S90 ; Pin back
G4 P500

Before the G28 command will reset the sensor in a way that it will alway (tm) work.

UPDATE: I added an alternative design "Distant" for the excellent "Mistral 2" cooling fanduct. This needs slightly changed firmware settings as follows:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -26
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 194

Some links to more information:

  • Marlin and auto levelling: http://marlinfw.org/docs/configuration/configuration.html
  • BL Touch: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bltouch-auto-bed-leveling-sensor-for-3d-printers
  • 3D-Touch: http://www.geeetech.com/wiki/index.php/3DTouch_Auto_Leveling_Sensor
  • SkyNet3D download: https://www.facebook.com/skynet3ddevelopment/?fref=ts
  • Anet A8 Marlin port sources: https://github.com/SkyNet3D/Marlin
  • "Just Blinking" ? Read this: http://www.geeetech.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=27&t=18263
    Thanks to "Tobi As" for the wiring overview image!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed it topside down to get best stiffness. The model was adjusted to print without supports.

comments.text: Zu Verkabelung kann ich so nichts sagen. Der Selbsttest ist schon ok aber was GND mit Z-Min vertauschen zu tun hat erschliesst sich mir da nicht. Ich würde erstmal nur orange/rot/schwarz anschliessen. Das sollte den Selbsttest machen und dann das "Servo" mit den M Befehlen ans Laufen bekommen. Damit muss er dann den Pin bewegen (M280 P0 S10 / M280 P0 S90). Dauertest (M280 P0 S120). Wenn gar nichts passiert, stimmt entweder die Verkabelung mit dem Display Pin nicht, oder die Firmware ist nicht korrekt konfiguriert. Zum M119 musst Du auch beachten, dass Du den Status nur bekommst, wenn Du den korrekten Test modus aktivierst (M280 P0 S60). Ansonsten zeigt M119 immer "open". Völlig egal was Du am Pin rumspielst.

comments.text:
; heat for printin
M851 Z0 ; Z-Offset to 0
G28 ; Homing in middle of bed
G1 X110 Y110 ; move nozzle to center
; move nozzle onto paper (gripping)
G92 Z0 ; define as 0 for Z
G30 X110 Y110 ; does probing in the center
; Z-offset is what G30 reports (negativ)
M851 Z-1.23 ; what G30 repots 1.23 in example
M500 ; write to EEPROM

author: hownocuc

title: Easier to print printable spool holder

description.text:
I was having issues printing out the original spool holder, so I made this one.  Basically, it's thicker which allows for better adhesion to the print bed for printers that aren't fully optimized yet, and I got rid of the rounded ends on the beams. The overhang was causing me problems initially.  
This will take longer to print than the old spool holder, but is probably sturdier and is certainly easier to print.  
If you need a temporary spool holder for while you print this, I used an old spindle used for holding CDs, put about 10 old CDs on it to acts as bearings, and then put my spool on that.  It worked well enough for my longer prints until I got this out.

Just print out the parts and press fit them together.  It's pretty tight, and it took me quite a bit of force.  
All that you need is two m3 screws and an m3 nut.  If your spools hole is too wide, you can look at the thing I remixed this from.  There are spool hole adapters there.

title: G27 Quick Release Steering Wheel Flanges

description.text:
Check out the video here.
I set up a G27 right upon my keyboard, which leaves me really limited space for typing. So I bought a quick release accessory for a standard steering wheel from Taobao. You can find a similar one by using keywords such as "Universal car steering quick release hub" on eBay (An example is this link. Again, mine does not come from that link.). Then I made these two flanges. I don't think FDM 3D printer provide outputs which are strong enough. I cut those out from a chunk of ABS.
Other things you will need:

  • T4.0 * 20 screw * 6
  • M5 * 8 screw * 6
  • M5 * 16 screw * 6
  • M4 * 12 screw * 6
  • M5 nuts
  • M4 nuts

UPDATE:

  1. 2017 Feb. 10th: adding spacers to flange2, otherwise tighten the steering wheel hard might ruin the flange.

title: Aus3D IR Probe Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a protective cover for the Aus3D IR probe v1.4
http://aus3d.com.au/ir-z-probe

The probe is based upon David Crocker's Mini IR height sensor board.
https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/

Rotate/Flip and print as you see fit.

IMPORTANT:
If you want to use PEI with this sensor I have found a dead simple solution that is giving me top notch results. Normally IR sensors have trouble with PEI surfaces because PEI is transparent to IR.

  • Step 1: scuff both sides of your PEI sheet with 600 grit sandpaper (or closest you have). Disclaimer: this first step may or may not make a difference, I personally like slightly scuffed PEI and it does help to "cloud up" the PEI some.

  • Step 2: Laminate your PEI to a piece of borosilicate glass as per usual with the standard 3m 468mp sheet tape.

  • Step 3: Take the standard blue painter's tape and stick it across your MIC 6 aluminum bed so as to cover most all of the bed surface. DO NOT overlap the painter's tape, just place each strip close to the one beside it.

  • Step 4: Place your nice glass and PEI sandwich (which is now easily removable from your main bed) onto the MIC 6 and fasten down however you like. I just used a few pieces of painters tape to hold it in place. Binder clips work too.

You should now have a PEI surface that works perfectly with the IR probe!!!

PIC: https://flic.kr/p/RQtetS Ignore the zits on that print, more retraction tweaking is underway.

title: Hot-end fan mount with dual air flow

description.text: With the new Slic3r "Cooling" option, using a fan in the hot-end to cool the layers faster is a great improvement in the print quality and speed. This part was designed to make it possible to cool down the hot-end heatsink and at the same time blow some air on the printed part, without dissipating heat from the hot-end itself. I was very inspired by thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16266 but also wanted to have airflow over the printed part.

This design was made using Sketchup, I will learn OpenScad soon and redesign it, I promise.
Use the .stl provided for the J-Head hot-end. It could work for others, but I encourage you to adapt the dimensions to your hot-end.
You can cover the plastic part that is closer to the nozzle with some kapton tape.
I have printed lots of things with this dual airflow system and it is working really well so far.

title: Stepper Motor Vehicle Axle Mount - Arduino basic kit.

description.text:
I want to make a basic R/C car from the basic Arduino starter kit.

Step one is mounting the included stepper motor to an axle for the rear drive wheels.

This is the minimalist mount for that - I am imagining that I'll fix it to a chassis using the two bolts already used in the project.

I'd like to not use any additional parts, but for now it needs an axle (mine seems to be 1.88mm diameter, I guess its supposed to be 2mm) and the two bolts are m4's

I plan to do a mount for the servo to do the steering at the front.... a mount for the arduino board... wheels, IR receiver (maybe bluetooth or wifi maybe GPS or whatever(!)) but this is a start.

The pictured item is one of each gear and the mount - the power gear goes on the stepper, the tight gear grips the axle and the loose gear is just for balance (maybe I'll do a differential.... for now it is probably not actually needed).

Printer:

Reprap Prusa i3 2017 model (from kit)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Still using all the default settings nothing special - printing in PLA.

Push fit - so may need tweaking for your printer/filament.

The drive gear is a tight push onto the stepper, the tight gear is a tight push onto the axle.

FreeCAD

I am getting better at FreeCAD - started setting out the centres of the holes and then just adding lines/arcs with tangents etc...

Had a few attempts tweeking the exact sizes for the towers, space between, size of holes for tight and lose fit.

The final photo is actually a slightly earlier prototype - the posts were too close together so I had to clip the tips of the drive gear(!) but It fitted and meshed in the end.

author: oregongeek

description.text: Iron Man Mark III Helmet 3d Print Files

The helmet files are scaled to a head size of 1 centimeter from ear to ear. This means that all you need to do is measure your head from ear to ear, then scale the part by whatever measurement your head is. For example, if your head is 23 centimeters ear to ear, you would scale the parts x23 or by 2300 percent. This way you can feel confident in scaling the parts yourselves the first time!

title: Light guides for Pocket Operator case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Light guides for Pocket Operator case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1375818
The video shows the light guides (printed by shapeways) in action.

These have not been tested for FDM printing! If you have some transparent filament, a good printer and want to try - please post your results!

Note: A version of case, buttons and light guides optimized for SLS/SLA printing also available at shapeways: https://www.shapeways.com/shops/cdb.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XGARLiMRdIk" ></iframe>

comments.text: I'm printing one of these cases this week, and will be trying your light guides with transparent filament.
comments.author: calculating

comments.text: I originally created the light guides for professional printing with stereolithography or laser sintering. I have never actually printed them using fused deposition modelling which most users have at home, so I can't give any suggestions. Except maybe that you will need excellent part cooling and probably support structures. Please post pictures of you print results (even if it fails!).
comments.author: calculating

comments.text: That's such a good idea, I never would have thought of printing a light guide, nice!
